Subject: Is it a bug in Matlab implementation of NEAT?
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=327416450; y=9-0k23GbTUh-QC61i8stZLIlfDQQTh6Rl_Qs5Fxd5v8GQJ4WANOn

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=ISO-8859-1

Hello,


Actually I played a bit with the original Matlab implementation code of NEAT
which I downloaded from
here<http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/soft-view.php?SoftID=23> that
includes the XOR experiment. I only changed the fitness function from
(4-individual_fitness)^2 to (81-individual_fitness)^2 (in xor_experiment
function). I have attached the results I got (Regression-NEAT1.jpg). Should
I consider it as a bug, since I could not interpret the results, specially
the fact that the maximum fitness plot is not a monotonically increasing
function.



The reason I did this experiment is because I wanted to see how good a
standard NEAT can approximate a function. So I generated 81 training samples
spanning [-2 : 0.5 : 2] with an output between 0 and 1 (the function
was [x*exp(-x^2
- y^2) + .5]). I only replace the XOR training data set with my training
data set and changed the activation function from
1./(1+exp(-4.9*population(index_individual).nodegenes(3,4:number_nodes))) to
1./(1+exp(-1*population(index_individual).nodegenes(3,4:number_nodes))) and
the fitness function as the one I mentioned above. Again I was expecting a
monotonically increasing function in maximum fitness plot
(Regression-NEAT2.jpg), but surprisingly this was not the case. I realized
that its maybe duo the fact that the species may die out. But the point is
that it never converge to an acceptable solution, even its not increasing,
but seems like a decreasing function. I have attached the results I got
after 1000 iterations.



I will appreciate if somebody could reflect on these results.



Thank you so much,

Mohsen.

--000e0cdfc978cd544704997cc0f8
Content-Type: text/html; charset=ISO-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
